description:
Asanoa ishikariensis is a species of bacteria that belongs to the genus Asanoa. It was first isolated from soil samples collected in Ishikari, Hokkaido, Japan.

Asanoa ishikariensis is a Gram-positive, aerobic, non-spore-forming, and non-motile bacterium. It has a coccoid or rod-shaped cell morphology and forms white to pale yellow-colored colonies on agar media.

Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequencing has shown that Asanoa ishikariensis is closely related to other members of the genus Asanoa, which are typically found in soil and marine environments.

The optimal growth conditions for Asanoa ishikariensis include a temperature range of 25-30Â°C and a pH range of 6.0-8.0. It has the ability to hydrolyze starch and casein, and it can utilize a variety of carbohydrates as carbon sources.

Further research is needed to fully understand the ecological role and potential applications of Asanoa ishikariensis in biotechnology or environmental processes.
